concept.title: How to use this document
concept.shortdesc: Read an overview of the information in each section of this document.

conbody.p: For encryption, supports Advanced Encryption Standard (AES), Data Encryption Standard (DES), public key cryptography (PKA or RSA), and Elliptic Curve Cryptography (ECC). These are very different cryptographic systems. Additionally, provides APIs for generating and verifying Message Authentication Codes (MACs), Hashed Message Authentication Codes (HMACs), hashes, and PINS, as well as other cryptographic functions.

includes the following chapters:
describes the programming considerations for using the verbs. It also explains the syntax and parameter definitions used in verbs. Information about concurrency is also provided.
describes the support for compliance-tagged tokens introduced with 6.0 It gives links to further related information in this document, and discusses the new warning mode to aid installations in detecting migration concerns.
gives an overview of AES, DES, and HMAC cryptography, and provides general guidance information on how these verbs use different key types and key forms.
introduces Public Key Algorithm (PKA) support and describes programming considerations for using the PKA and ECC verbs, such as the PKA key token structure and key management.
introduces TR-31 support and how uses an IBM-defined optional block in a TR-31 key block.
provides information about master key management.

ul.li: describes using the resource control verbs.

describes the verbs for generating and maintaining DES and AES cryptographic keys, the verb (which generates 8-byte random numbers), the verb (which generates up to 8192 bytes of random content), and the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) security protocol. This chapter also describes utilities to build DES and AES tokens, generate and translate control vectors, and describes the PKA verbs that support DES and AES key distribution.
describes the verbs for enciphering and deciphering data.

describes the verbs for generating and verifying Message Authentication Codes (MACs), generating and verifying Hashed Message Authentication Codes (HMACs), generating Modification Detection Codes (MDCs), and generating hashes (SHA-1, SHA-224, SHA-256, SHA-384, SHA-512, MD5, RIPEMD-160).
describes the use of key storage, key tokens, and associated verbs.

describes the verbs for use in support of finance-industry applications. This includes several categories.
Verbs for generating, verifying, and translating personal identification numbers (PINS).
Verbs that generate and verify VISA card verification values and card security codes.
Verbs to support smart card applications using the EMV (Europay MasterCard Visa) standards.
describes the verbs for PIN methods and requirements for financial services specified by the German Banking Industry Committee, Deutsche Kreditwirtschaft (DK).
describes the verbs used to manage TR-34 key blocks and TR-34 functions.
describes the verbs used to manage TR-31 key blocks and TR-31 functions.
describes the verbs that support using digital signatures to authenticate messages.
describes the verbs that generate and manage PKA keys.
describes the utility verb which is provided for code conversion.
explains the return and reason codes returned by the verbs.

describes the formats for AES, DES internal, external, and null key tokens, for PKA public, private external, and private internal key tokens containing Rivest-Shamir-Adleman (RSA) information, PKA null key tokens, ECC key tokens, HMAC key tokens, Transaction Validation Values (TVVs), and trusted blocks.
describes the key forms and types used by the verb.

contains a table of the default control vector values that are associated with each key type and describes the control information for testing control vectors, mask array preparation, selecting the key-half processing mode, and an example of using the verb.
introduces a DK key type vector (KTV) which is used to define how to generate or derive the intended AES variable-length symmetric key.
describes the PIN notation, formats, extraction rules, and algorithms.
describes various ciphering and key verification algorithms, as well as the formatting of hashes and keys.
lists the access control points and their corresponding verbs.
documents the data structures that are used in the access control system.
informs about how to manage keys, verbs and applications that should apply the compliance standard.
presents information about the use of AES keys with derived unique key per transaction (DUKPT) processing.
contains sample verb call routines, both in C and Java, that illustrates the practical application of CCA verb calls.
includes tips to help you set up your system for the first time.
includes RPM installation, configuration, and uninstallation instructions.
includes information about using various versions of features in the same system, and other restrictions.
describes the ivp.e and panel.exe utilities.
contains an alphabetical list of security API command and sub-command codes returned by the output rule-array for option STATDIAG of the verb.
provides information about which is an open source implementation of the Cryptoki API as defined by the industry-wide Cryptographic Token Interface Standard.
contains definitions of abbreviations used.
